citation.article-title: Alcanivorax borkumensis gen. nov., sp. nov., a new, hydrocarbon-degrading and surfactant-producing marine bacterium.

p.s: Alcanivorax (Al'.ca.ni.vo'.rax. M.L. masc. n. alcanum alkane, aliphatic hydrocarbon; L. adj. vorax voracious, gluttonous; M.L. masc. n. Alcanivorax alkane-devouring)
Gram-negative non-motile aerobic rods that are generally 0.6-0.8 μm wide and 16-25 μm long when growing in pyruvate-supplemented medium.
They are shorter (1.0-1.5 μm) when n-alkanes are used as single carbon and energy source.
Aliphatic hydrocarbons are used as sole or principal carbon sources for growth.
A mixture of active biosurfactants, glucose lipids, are produced, one of which consists of four 3-hydroxydecanoic acids linked together by ester bonds and coupled glycosidically with C-1 of glucose.
The G + C content of the DNA isolated from six strains of the single species is 53-54 mol%.
The type and only species of the genus is Alcanivorax borkumensis.
